Author: Adam Shepard

Author: Adib Khorram

Annotator Notes: "''I had an eye on my fellow white South Africans and white Americans when I wrote the book,'' Mr. Paton said."

Author: Albert Camus

Author: Aldous Huxley

Author: Alexander Solzhenitsyn

Author: Alexandre Dumas
Annotator Notes: "Their parents were Marie-Louise Élisabeth Labouret, the daughter of an innkeeper, and Thomas-Alexandre Dumas. Thomas-Alexandre had been born in the French colony of Saint-Domingue (now Haiti), the mixed-race, natural son of the marquis Alexandre Antoine Davy de la Pailleterie (Antoine), a French nobleman and général commissaire in the artillery of the colony, and Marie-Cessette Dumas, an enslaved woman of Afro-Caribbean ancestry."

Author: Alice Walker
Annotator Notes: "In 1982, she became the first African-American woman to win the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction, which she was awarded for her novel The Color Purple"

Author: Amy Tan
Annotator Notes: "Born in the U.S. to immigrant parents from China, Amy Tan grew up in the San Francisco Bay Area in a succession of twelve homes by the time she graduated from high school. "

Author: An Na
Annotator Notes: "An Na (born 1972) is a South Korea-born[1] American children's book author."

Author: Angie Thomas
Annotator Notes: ""I think a lot of African-Americans can understand that,” she says. “Especially if you’re put into a lot of white spaces – like me today,”"

Author: Ann Petry
Annotator Notes: "Her 1946 debut novel The Street became the first novel by an African-American woman to sell more than a million copies."

Author: Anne Frank
Annotator Notes: "The Franks were liberal Jews, and did not observe all of the customs and traditions of Judaism"

Author: Anne Tyler

Author: Anthony Doerr

Author: Anthony Trollope
Annotator Notes: "was an English novelist and civil servant of the Victorian era" " son of landed gentry"

Author: Arturo Islas
Annotator Notes: "Arturo Islas, Jr. was a novelist from El Paso, Texas, whose writing focused on the experience of Chicano cultural duality" "Islas lived with Jay Spears until they broke up in 1970. Islas learned in 1985 that Spears was in hospital with AIDS, from which he died in 1986. Islas himself died of complications related to AIDS on 15 February 1991 at his campus home."

Author: Arundhati Roy
Annotator Notes: "Arundhati Roy was born in Shillong, Meghalaya, India, to Mary Roy, a Malayali Jacobite Syrian Christian women's rights activist from Kerala and Rajib Roy, a Bengali Hindu tea plantation manager from Calcutta."

Author: Barack Obama
Annotator Notes: "He was born to an American mother and a Kenyan father."

Author: Barbara Kingsolver

Author: Benjamin Alire Saenz

Author: Betty Smith

Author: Cherie Dimaline
Annotator Notes: Cherie Dimaline is an Indigenous Canadian writer from the Georgian Bay Métis Nation, a part of Métis Nation of Ontario. She has written a variety of award-winning novels and other acclaimed stories and articles.

Author: Cheryl Strayed
Annotator Notes: Cheryl Strayed is an American writer and podcast host. She has written four books: the novel Torch and the nonfiction books Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail, Tiny Beautiful Things and Brave Enough.

Author: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
Annotator Notes: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (/ˌtʃɪmɑːˈmɑːndə əŋˈɡoʊzi əˈdiːtʃeɪ/ (listen) CHIM-ah-MAHN-də əng-GOH-zee ə-DEE-chay;[note 1] born 15 September 1977)[3][4] is a Nigerian writer whose works include novels, short stories and nonfiction.[5] She was described in The Times Literary Supplement as "the most prominent" of a "procession of critically acclaimed young anglophone authors [which] is succeeding in attracting a new generation of readers to African literature",[6] particularly in her second home, the United States.

Author: Chinua Achebe
Annotator Notes: Chinua Achebe was a Nigerian novelist, poet, and critic who is regarded as the dominant figure of modern African literature. His first novel and magnum opus, Things Fall Apart, occupies a pivotal place in African literature and remains the most widely studied, translated, and read African novel.

Author: Chitra Banerjee Divakaruni
Annotator Notes: Chitra Banerjee Divakaruni is an Indian-born American author, poet, and the Betty and Gene McDavid Professor of Writing at the University of Houston Creative Writing Program. Her short story collection, Arranged Marriage, won an American Book Award in 1996.

Author: Claude McKay
Annotator Notes: Festus Claudius "Claude" McKay OJ was a Jamaican-American writer and poet. He was a central figure in the Harlem Renaissance. Born in Jamaica, McKay first travelled to the United States to attend college, and encountered W. E. B

Author: Cormac McCarthy
Annotator Notes: "His family were Irish Catholics."

Author: Cristina Garcia
Annotator Notes: Cristina García is a Cuban-born American journalist and novelist. Her first novel Dreaming in Cuban was a finalist for the National Book Award.

Author: Cristina Henríquez
Annotator Notes: "Henríquez's father is from Panama and immigrated to the U.S. in 1971 for college". Author's book is about Panamanian immigrants

Author: Daniel Defoe
Annotator Notes: "His father, James Foe, was a prosperous tallow chandler of Flemish descent"

Author: Darnell L. Moore
Annotator Notes: "For powerful autobiographical reflections on growing up in Camden, NJ, see his two-part essay "Reflections of a Black Queer Suicide Survivor":"

Author: Dashka Slater
Annotator Notes: "She grew up in Cambridge, Massachusetts but has spent most of her adult life in Oakland, California, where she is always working on far too many writing projects."

Annotator Notes: "David Wroblewski was born in Oconomowoc, Wisconsin, near Milwaukee.

Annotator Notes: "She was related to the Rensselaers, the most prestigious of the old patroon families"

Author: Elizabeth Acevedo
Annotator Notes: "Elizabeth Acevedo is an Afro-Dominican performer and author of THE POET X

Author: Elizabeth Strout
Annotator Notes: "Elizabeth Strout was born in Portland, Maine, and grew up in small towns in Maine and New Hampshire."

Author: Emile Zola

Annotator Notes: "Emily Brontë was born on 30 July 1818 to Maria Branwell and an Irish father, Patrick Brontë."

Annotator Notes: "Erika L. Sánchez is a Mexican-American poet, novelist, and essayist."

Author: Ernest Gaines
Annotator Notes: "In Gaines’s childhood, the center of his world was Cherie Quarter, the former slave quarter on River Lake Plantation, where five generations of his family had lived.

Annotator Notes: "Much of Hemingway’s brand of masculinity was bound up in a white ideal as a kind of understood standard against which everything was to be measured."

Annotator Notes: "Ernesto Quiñonez (born 1965) is an Ecuadorian-Puerto Rican novelist.

Author: Evelyn Waugh
Annotator Notes: "Arthur Evelyn St. John Waugh was born on 28 October 1903 to Arthur Waugh (1866–1943) and Catherine Charlotte Raban (1870–1954), into a family with English, Scottish, Welsh, Irish and Huguenot origins."

Author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
Annotator Notes: "His mother was Mary "Molly" McQuillan Fitzgerald, the daughter of an Irish immigrant who became wealthy as a wholesale grocer. His father, Edward Fitzgerald, descended from Irish and English ancestry"

Annotator Notes: "She is a first-generation Chinese American author"

Author: Fiona Mozley
Annotator Notes: "Fiona Mozley was born in 1988 in the London Borough of Hackney, and now lives in Edinburgh. She used to live in York, where she grew up and attended Fulford School."

Author: Flannery O'Connor
Annotator Notes: "O'Connor was born on March 25, 1925, in Savannah, Georgia, the only child of Edward Francis O'Connor, a real estate agent, and Regina Cline, who were both of Irish descent"

Annotator Notes: "Ford Madox Ford was an English novelist, poet, critic and editor"

Author: Frances Hodgson Burnett
Annotator Notes: "She was the third of five children of Edwin Hodgson, an ironmonger from Doncaster in Yorkshire, and his wife Eliza Boond, from a well-to-do Manchester family."

Author: Francisco Jiménez
Annotator Notes: "Francisco Jiménez (born June 29, 1943 in Tlaquepaque, Mexico) is a Mexican-American writer and professor at Santa Clara University in Santa Clara, California."

Author: Frank Norris

Author: Franz Kafka

Author: Frederick Douglass
Annotator Notes: "Douglass was of mixed race, which likely included Native American and African on his mother's side, as well as European"

Author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
Annotator Notes: "Dostoevsky's paternal ancestors were part of a noble family of Russian Orthodox Christians. The family traced its roots back to Danilo Irtishch, who was granted lands in the Pinsk region (for centuries part of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, now in modern-day Belarus"

Author: Gabriel García Márquez
Annotator Notes: "Gabriel García Márquez was born on 6 March 1927 in Aracataca, Colombia, to Gabriel Eligio García and Luisa Santiaga Márquez Iguarán"

Author: Geoffrey Canada
Annotator Notes: "Coming to terms with mixed roots can be surprising and sometimes even painful. Educator Geoffrey Canada visits Franklin County Virginia where, a white man possibly fathered one of his enslaved ancestors more than a century ago."

Author: George Eliot
Annotator Notes: "Mary Ann Evans (22 November 1819 – 22 December 1880; alternatively Mary Anne or Marian), known by her pen name George Eliot, was an English novelist, poet, journalist, translator, and one of the leading writers of the Victorian era"

Author: George Jenkins
Annotator Notes: "We Beat the Street: How a Friendship Pact Led to Success is an American autobiography aimed at young adults written by The Three Doctors and Sharon M. Draper" "The Three Doctors is a group of African-American motivational speakers, authors, and doctors"

Annotator Notes: "She is a five-time winner of the Coretta Scott King Award"

Author: George M. Johnson
Annotator Notes: "George M. Johnson, is a queer Black American author" "Johnson is queer and non-binary."

Author: George Orwell

Author: Gish Jen
Annotator Notes: "Gish Jen is a second-generation Chinese American."

Author: Gloria Naylor
Annotator Notes: "The Naylors, who had been sharecroppers in Robinsonville, Mississippi, had migrated to Harlem to escape life in the segregated South"

Author: Gustave Flaubert
Annotator Notes: "Flaubert was born in Rouen, in the Seine-Maritime department of Upper Normandy, in northern France. He was the second son of Anne Justine Caroline (née Fleuriot; 1793–1872) and Achille-Cléophas Flaubert (1784–1846), director and senior surgeon of the major hospital in Rouen"

Author: H. G. Bissinger
Annotator Notes: "Harry Gerard Bissinger III, also known as Buzz Bissinger and H. G. Bissinger (born November 1, 1954) is an American journalist and author"

Author: Ha Jin
Annotator Notes: "Jin Xuefei is a Chinese-American poet and novelist using the pen name Ha Jin"

Author: Harper Lee
Annotator Notes: "Through her father, she was related to Confederate General Robert E. Lee". Harper Lee is also a well-known example of a white author writing about Black characters

Author: Harriet Beecher Stowe
Annotator Notes: "Harriet Elisabeth Beecher Stowe (/stoʊ/; June 14, 1811 – July 1, 1896) was an American author and abolitionist."

Author: Haruki Murakami
Annotator Notes: "Murakami was born in Kyoto, Japan, during the post-World War II baby boom and raised in Nishinomiya, Ashiya and Kobe. He is an only child. His father was the son of a Buddhist priest, and his mother is the daughter of an Osaka merchant"

Author: Héctor Tobar
Annotator Notes: Tobar is the son of Guatemalan immigrants. His long career in journalism includes work for The New Yorker, LA Weekly, and many positions at the Los Angeles Times.

Author: Henry David Thoreau
Annotator Notes: Henry David Thoreau (July 12, 1817 – May 6, 1862) was an American naturalist, essayist, poet, and philosopher

Author: Henry Fielding
Annotator Notes: Henry Fielding was an English novelist, irony writer, and dramatist known for earthy humour and satire. His comic novel Tom Jones is still widely appreciated.

Author: Henry James
Annotator Notes: Henry James was an American Gothic author, best known for his works, The Turn of the Screw, The Portrait of a Lady, and The American. He was born in New York on the 15th of April 1843. His parents were of Irish descent with his paternal grandparents hailing from Bailieborough, Co. Cavan.

Author: Herman Melville
Annotator Notes: Herman was the third of eight children in a family of Scottish and Dutch descent.

Author: Hermann Hesse
Annotator Notes: Hermann Karl Hesse (German: [ˈhɛʁman ˈhɛsə] ( listen); 2 July 1877 – 9 August 1962) was a German-Swiss poet, novelist, and painter.

Author: Homeira Qaderi
Annotator Notes: "She was born in Kabul, Afghanistan during the Russian occupation to an artist mother and a father who is a high school teacher. Dr. Qaderi's early childhood was spent first sheltering from the Soviets and then from the civil war following the Soviet withdrawal."

Author: Ian McEwan
Annotator Notes: "His father was a working-class Scotsman who had worked his way up through the army to the rank of major"

Author: Immaculee Ilibagiza
Annotator Notes: "Immaculée Ilibagiza (born 1972) is a Rwandan American author and motivational speaker. "

Author: Isaak Dinesen
Annotator Notes: "Baroness Karen Christenze von Blixen-Finecke (born Dinesen; 17 April 1885 – 7 September 1962) was a Danish author who wrote works in Danish and English. She is also known under her pen names Isak Dinesen, used in English-speaking countries,"

Author: Isabel Allende
Annotator Notes: "Allende was born in Lima, Peru, the daughter of Francisca Llona Barros called "Doña Panchita" (the daughter of Agustín Llona Cuevas and Isabel Barros Moreira, of Portuguese descent) and Tomás Allende, who was at the time a second secretary at the Chilean embassy."

Author: Isabel Quintero
Annotator Notes: "Isabel Quintero is a writer and the daughter of Mexican immigrants."

Author: Isabel Wilkerson
Annotator Notes: "She won the Pulitzer Prize for Feature Writing in 1994, as Chicago Bureau Chief of The New York Times, making her the first African-American woman to win a Pulitzer Prize in journalism"

Author: Ishmael Beah
Annotator Notes: "In 1991, the Sierra Leone Civil War started. Rebels invaded Beah's hometown, Mogbwemo, located in the Southern Province of Sierra Leone, and he was forced to flee."

Author: J.D. Salinger
Annotator Notes: "His father, Sol Salinger, traded in Kosher cheese, and was from a family of Lithuanian-Jewish descent... Salinger's mother, Marie (née Jillich), was born in Atlantic, Iowa, of German, Irish, and Scottish descent"

Author: Jamal Joseph
Annotator Notes: "Jamal Joseph was born Edward L. Joseph in New York City. His parents, who never married, were both Afro-Cuban; his father, Alipio Zorilla, was a revolutionary comrade of Fidel Castro"

Author: James Baldwin
Annotator Notes: "James Arthur Baldwin (August 2, 1924 – December 1, 1987) was an African American writer." "The only out gay men in the movement were Baldwin and Bayard Rustin"

Author: James Fenimore Cooper
Annotator Notes: "Shortly after James' first birthday, (1790) his family moved to Cooperstown, New York, a community founded by his father on a large piece of land which he had bought for development. Later, his father was elected to the United States Congress as a representative from Otsego County"

Author: James Joyce
Annotator Notes: "Joyce was born in Dublin into a middle-class family. He attended the Jesuit Clongowes Wood College in County Kildare, then, briefly, the Christian Brothers-run O'Connell School."

Author: James McBride
Annotator Notes: "McBride's father, Rev. Andrew D. McBride (August 8, 1911 – April 5, 1957) was African-American; he died of cancer at the age of 45. His mother, Ruchel Dwajra Zylska (name changed to Rachel Deborah Shilsky, and later to Ruth McBride Jordan; April 1, 1921 – January 9, 2010), was a Jewish immigrant from Poland"

Author: James Weldon Johnson
Annotator Notes: "Johnson was born in 1871 in Jacksonville, Florida, the son of James Johnson, a Mulatto headwaiter and Helen Louise Dillet, a native of Nassau and Bahamas."

Author: Jane Austen
Annotator Notes: "Jane Austen (/ˈɒstɪn, ˈɔːs-/; 16 December 1775 – 18 July 1817) was an English novelist known primarily for her six major novels, which interpret, critique, and comment upon the British landed gentry at the end of the 18th century"

Author: Jane Smiley
Annotator Notes: "Jane Smiley (born September 26, 1949) is an American novelist. She won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 1992 for her novel A Thousand Acres (1991)."

Author: Janet Mock
Annotator Notes: "Her father, Charlie Mock III, is African-American, and her mother, Elizabeth (née Barrett), is of half Portuguese descent, part Asian descent and part Native Hawaiian (kānaka maoli) descent"

Author: Jason Reynolds
Annotator Notes: "At nine years old, Reynolds was inspired by Queen Latifah's third album, Black Reign, to start writing poetry. Outside of her rap, few literary works spoke to his experience of urban life growing up as a black child and then teenager in the 1980s and 1990s, and he didn't start reading books until he was 17."

Author: Brendan Kiely
Annotator Notes: "His most recent book is The Other Talk: Reckoning with Our White Privilege"

Author: Jay Asher
Annotator Notes: "Asher was born in Arcadia, California, on September 30, 1975. He is half Jewish."

Author: Jean Rhys
Annotator Notes: "Rhys's father, William Rees Williams, was a Welsh medical doctor and her mother, Minna Williams, née Lockhart, a third-generation Dominican Creole of Scots ancestry. ("Creole" was broadly used in those times to refer to any person born on the island, whether they were of European or African descent, or both.)"

Author: Jeanette Winterson
Annotator Notes: "Winterson was born in Manchester and adopted by Constance and John William Winterson on 21 January 1960. She grew up in Accrington, Lancashire, and was raised in the Elim Pentecostal Church." "By the age of 16, Winterson had come out as a lesbian and left home"

Author: Jeannette Walls
Annotator Notes: "Jeannette Walls (born April 21, 1960) is an American author and journalist widely known as former gossip columnist for MSNBC.com and author of The Glass Castle, a memoir of the nomadic family life of her childhood"

Author: Jeff Garvin
Annotator Notes: "Jeff Garvin is a writer and actor from Orange County, California. He has made guest star appearances on network TV and independent films spanning three decades. Jeff is also as an award-winning author."

Author: Jeffrey Eugenides
Annotator Notes: "Eugenides was born in Detroit, Michigan to a father of Greek descent and a mother of English and Irish ancestry"

Author: Jesmyn Ward
Annotator Notes: "She is the only woman and only African American to win the National Book Award for Fiction twice.

Author: Jhumpa Lahiri
Annotator Notes: "Lahiri was born in London, the daughter of Indian immigrants from the Indian state of West Bengal.

Author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
Annotator Notes: "Goethe was one of the very few figures of Germany’s 18th-century literary renaissance who were, in the full sense of the term, bourgeois.

Author: John E. Wideman
Annotator Notes: "he became the second African American to win a Rhodes Scholarship

Author: John Gardner
Annotator Notes: "John Champlin Gardner Jr. (July 21, 1933 – September 14, 1982) was an American novelist, essayist, literary critic and university professor.

Author: John Green
Annotator Notes: "The thing is, we can’t pretend John Green’s whiteness, his maleness, and his heterosexuality aren’t central to his brand."

Author: John Irving
Annotator Notes: "New England pale-face, novelist John Irving, has taken a stand"

Author: John Knowles
Annotator Notes: "Knowles was born on September 17, 1926" "His father was a coal company executive"

Author: John Steinbeck
Annotator Notes: "He was of German, English, and Irish descent

Author: Jon Krakauer
Annotator Notes: " His father was Jewish and his mother was a Unitarian of Scandinavian descent."

Author: Jonathan Safran Foer
Annotator Notes: "Safran Foer is the middle son of a Jewish family. "

Author: Jonathan Swift
Annotator Notes: "Jonathan Swift was born on 30 November 1667 in Dublin in the Kingdom of Ireland." "His father was a native of Goodrich, Herefordshire" "His maternal grandfather, James Ericke, was the vicar of Thornton in Leicestershire"

Annotator Notes: "José Antonio Villarreal (30 July 1924 – 13 January 2010) was an American Chicano novelist."

Author: Joseph Conrad

Annotator Notes: "Oates was born in Lockport, New York, the eldest of three children of Carolina (née Bush), a homemaker of Hungarian descent"

Annotator Notes: "Juan Gabriel Vásquez (born in Bogotá on January 1, 1973) is a Colombian writer, journalist and translator."

Annotator Notes: "Many of Alvarez's works are influenced by her experiences as a Dominican-American"

Annotator Notes: "Both of her parents were of Japanese descent, with her father being an issei and her mother being a nisei"

Author: Junot Díaz

Author: Justin Torres
Annotator Notes: "Justin Torres was born to a father of Puerto Rican descent and a mother of Italian and Irish descent"

Author: Kacen Callender
Annotator Notes: "Callender is Black, queer, trans, and uses they/them and he/him pronouns"

Author: Kao Kalia Yang
Annotator Notes: "Kao Kalia Yang (born 1980) is a Hmong American writer "

Author: Karla Cornejo Villavicencio
Annotator Notes: "Karla Cornejo Villavicencio (born 1989) is an Ecuadorian-American writer "

Author: Kate Chopin
Annotator Notes: "Of maternal French and paternal Irish descent, Chopin was born in St. Louis, Missouri."

Author: Kathryn Stockett
Annotator Notes: "She is known for her 2009 debut novel, The Help, which is about African-American maids working in white households in Jackson, Mississippi, during the 1960s." "Reflective of her first novel, Stockett was very close to an African American domestic worker."

Author: Kazuo Ishiguro
Annotator Notes: Sir Kazuo Ishiguro OBE FRSA FRSL is a Japanese-British novelist, screenwriter, musician, and short-story writer. Ishiguro was born in Nagasaki, Japan, and moved to Britain in 1960 with his parents when he was five

Author: Kelly Parra
Annotator Notes: "Kelly is multicultural. She went all out and had her DNA tested. Her nationalities are Mexican, Filipino, and Italian, with some light ancestorial markers in between."

Author: Ken Kesey
Annotator Notes: Ken Elton Kesey was an American novelist, essayist and countercultural figure. He considered himself a link between the Beat Generation of the 1950s and the hippies of the 1960s. Kesey was born in La Junta, Colorado, and grew up in Springfield, Oregon, graduating from the University of Oregon in 1957.

Author: Khaled Hosseini
Annotator Notes: Khaled Hosseini is an Afghan-American novelist, UNHCR goodwill ambassador, and former physician. His debut novel The Kite Runner was a critical and commercial success; the book and his subsequent novels have all been at least partially set in Afghanistan and have featured an Afghan as the protagonist

Author: Kim Edwards
Annotator Notes: "Kim Edwards (born May 4, 1958) is an American author and educator. She was born in Killeen, Texas, grew up in the Finger Lakes region of upstate New York, and graduated from Colgate University and The University of Iowa"

Author: Kiran Desai
Annotator Notes: "Kiran Desai (born 3 September 1971) is an Indian author. "

Author: Kurt Vonnegut
Annotator Notes: "He had descended from German immigrants who settled in the United States in the mid-19th century;"

Author: Lan Cao
Annotator Notes: "She was born in Saigon, South Vietnam and grew up in Saigon's twin city, Cholon. In 1975, when communist forces defeated South Vietnam, she was flown out of Vietnam."

Author: Laura Esquivel
Annotator Notes: Laura Beatriz Esquivel Valdés is a Mexican novelist, screenwriter and politician, serving in the LXIII Legislature of the Mexican Congress in the Chamber of Deputies for the Morena Party from 2015 to 2018.

Author: Laurie Halse Anderson
Annotator Notes: Laurie Halse Anderson is an American writer, known for children's and young adult novels.

Author: Leo Tolstoy
Annotator Notes: Count Lev Nikolayevich Tolstoy, usually referred to in English as Leo Tolstoy, was a Russian writer who is regarded as one of the greatest authors of all time.

Author: Leslie Marmon Silko
Annotator Notes: "Her mixed-race family was of white American, Native American, and Mexican descent."

Author: Lewis Carroll
Annotator Notes: Charles Lutwidge Dodgson , better known by his pen name Lewis Carroll, was an English author, poet and mathematician.

Author: Lisa See
Annotator Notes: "Her paternal great-grandfather Fong See (鄺泗) was Chinese, making her one-eighth Chinese. This has had a great impact on her life and work. She has written for and led in many cultural events emphasizing the importance of Los Angeles and Chinatown."

Author: Lois Lowry
Annotator Notes: "Initially, Lowry's parents named her "Cena" for her Norwegian grandmother, but upon hearing the news, her grandmother telegraphed and instructed Lowry's parents that the child should have an American name"

Author: Louis Sachar
Annotator Notes: "Sachar was born to a religious Jewish family in East Meadow, New York. "

Author: Louisa May Alcott
Annotator Notes: "Little Women is set in the Alcott family home, Orchard House, in Concord, Massachusetts, and is loosely based on Alcott's childhood"

Author: Louise Erdrich
Annotator Notes: "She was the oldest of seven children born to Ralph Erdrich, a German-American, and Rita (née Gourneau), a Chippewa woman (of half Ojibwe and half French blood)"

Author: Louise O'Neill
Annotator Notes: "Louise O'Neill is an Irish author who writes primarily for young adults. She was born in 1985 and grew up in Clonakilty, in West Cork, Ireland."

Author: Loung Ung
Annotator Notes: "Loung Ung (Khmer: អ៊ឹង លួង; born 19 November 1970) is a Cambodian American human-rights activist, lecturer and national spokesperson for the Campaign for a Landmine-Free World, between 1997 and 2003."

Author: Luis J. Rodriguez
Annotator Notes: "Rodriguez is recognized as a major figure in contemporary Chicano literature, identifying himself as a native Xicanx writer"

Author: M.T. Anderson
Annotator Notes: "Anderson was born in Cambridge, Massachusetts. His father Will Anderson was an engineer, and his mother Juliana Anderson was an Episcopal priest."

Author: Madeline Miller
Annotator Notes: "Madeline Miller (born July 24, 1978) is an American novelist, author of The Song of Achilles (2011) and Circe (2018). "

Author: Malala Yousafzai
Annotator Notes: "Her family is Sunni Muslim of Pashtun ethnicity, belonging to the Yusufzai tribe."

Author: Margaret Ajemian Ahnert
Annotator Notes: Margaret Ahnert was born in New York City in 1938. Growing up, she loved to hear her mother's stories about her own childhood during the Armenian genocide in Turkey.

Author: Margaret Atwood
Annotator Notes: Margaret Eleanor Atwood CC OOnt CH FRSC FRSL is a Canadian poet, novelist, literary critic, essayist, teacher, environmental activist, and inventor.

Author: Margaret Laurence
Annotator Notes: Jean Margaret Laurence CC was a Canadian novelist and short story writer, and is one of the major figures in Canadian literature. She was also a founder of the Writers' Trust of Canada, a non-profit literary organization that seeks to encourage Canada's writing community.

Author: Maria Testa
Annotator Notes: Maria Testa (5 February 1956 – 13 September 2009) was an Italian archer.

Author: Marilynne Robinson
Annotator Notes: Marilynne Summers Robinson (born November 26, 1943) is an American novelist and essayist.

Author: Mark Twain
Annotator Notes: "Twain was of Cornish, English, and Scots-Irish descent"

Author: Markus Zusak
Annotator Notes: Markus Zusak is an Australian writer with Austrian and German roots.

Author: Martin Luther King, Jr.
Annotator Notes: "An African-American church leader and a son of early civil rights activist and minister Martin Luther King Sr., King advanced civil rights for people of color in the United States through nonviolence and civil disobedience. "

Author: Mary Shelley
Annotator Notes: "Mary Shelley was born Mary Wollstonecraft Godwin in Somers Town, London, in 1797. She was the second child of the feminist philosopher, educator, and writer Mary Wollstonecraft and the first child of the philosopher, novelist, and journalist William Godwin"

Author: Matthew Desmond
Annotator Notes: "Matthew Desmond is a sociologist and the Maurice P. During Professor of Sociology at Princeton University, where he is also the principal investigator of the Eviction Lab."

Author: Matthew Kaopio
Annotator Notes: "The Kamehameha Schools graduate is the one of the founding Hawaii artists in a newly emerging professional business initiative for native Hawaiian artists and others with disabilities."

Author: Max Brooks
Annotator Notes: "He is the son of comedy filmmaker Mel Brooks and actress Anne Bancroft."

Author: Maxine Hong Kingston
Annotator Notes: "Kingston was born Maxine Ting Ting Hong on October 27, 1940, in Stockton, California, to first-generation Chinese immigrants,"

Author: Maya Angelou
Annotator Notes: "She was respected as a spokesperson for Black people and women, and her works have been considered a defense of Black culture" "In "an astonishing exception"[8] to the harsh economics of African Americans of the time, Angelou's grandmother prospered financially during the Great Depression and World War II "

Author: Michael Dorris
Annotator Notes: "Michael Dorris was born in Louisville, Kentucky to Mary Besy (née Burkhardt) and Jim Dorris. (The senior Dorris was later reported as mixed race, with a Native American father.)"

Author: Michael Herr
Annotator Notes: "His family was Jewish

Author: Michael Ondaatje
Annotator Notes: "Ondaatje was born in Colombo, Sri Lanka in 1943, of Burgher descent (Dutch and Sinhalese)"

Author: Michael Patrick MacDonald
Annotator Notes: "He is of Irish descent."

Author: Michelle Zauner
Annotator Notes: "Her mother was Korean and her father is American of Jewish heritage."

Author: Miguel de Cervantes
Annotator Notes: "Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra was an Early Modern Spanish writer"

Author: MK Asante
Annotator Notes: "Born in Harare, Zimbabwe and raised in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Asante is the son of scholar Molefi Kete Asante and choreographer Kariamu Welsh."

Author: Moustafa Bayoumi
Annotator Notes: "He is of Egyptian descent."

Author: Muriel Spark
Annotator Notes: " Her father was Jewish, born in Edinburgh of Lithuanian immigrant parents, and her English mother had been raised Anglican"

Author: N Scott Momaday
Annotator Notes: "He was delivered in the Kiowa and Comanche Indian Hospital, registered as having seven-eighths Indian blood

Author: Nancy Farmer
Annotator Notes: "Nancy Farmer is an American author of children's and young adult books and science fiction."

Author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
Annotator Notes: "William Hathorne, the author's great-great-great-grandfather, was a Puritan and the first of the family to emigrate from England. "

Author: Nawal El Saadawi
Annotator Notes: "Her Upper Egyptian father was a government official in the Ministry of Education, who had campaigned against the British occupation of Egypt during the Egyptian Revolution of 1919"

Author: Neal Shusterman
Annotator Notes: "His family is Jewish"

Author: Neil deGrasse Tyson
Annotator Notes: "His African-American father, Cyril deGrasse Tyson" "His mother, Sunchita Maria Tyson (née Feliciano; born 1928), was a gerontologist for the U.S. Department of Health, Education and Welfare, and is of Puerto Rican descent"

Author: Nella Larsen
Annotator Notes: "Her mother was Pederline Marie Hansen, a Danish immigrant," "Her father was Peter Walker, believed to be a mixed-race Afro-Caribbean immigrant from the Danish West Indies."

Author: Nic Stone
Annotator Notes: "She is African-American and is openly bisexual."

Author: Nietzsche
Annotator Notes: "Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche was a German philosopher, prose poet, cultural critic, philologist, and composer whose work has exerted a profound influence on contemporary philosophy"

Author: Nikki Grimes
Annotator Notes: "Her novel Bronx Masquerade was named the Coretta Scott King Award book in 2002. The Coretta Scott King Award is "given to African-American authors and illustrators for outstanding inspirational and educational contributions.""

Author: Norman Maclean
Annotator Notes: "In his novella, A River Runs Through It, Norman Maclean wrote that his paternal ancestors were from the Isle of Mull, in the Inner Hebrides of Scotland. According to his son, however, their paternal ancestors were Gaelic speaking Presbyterians and from the Isle of Coll, which is "located about seven miles west of the Clan MacLean stronghold, the Isle of Mull"."

Author: NoViolet Bulawayo
Annotator Notes: "Her debut novel, We Need New Names, was shortlisted for the 2013 Booker Prize, and her second novel, Glory, was shortlisted for the 2022 Booker Prize, making her "the first Black African woman to appear on the Booker list twice""

Author: Octavia E. Butler
Annotator Notes: "Growing up in the racially integrated community of Pasadena allowed Butler to experience cultural and ethnic diversity in the midst of racial segregation. She accompanied her mother to her cleaning work where, as workers, the two entered white people's houses through back doors. Her mother was treated poorly by her employers"

Author: Oliver Goldsmith
Annotator Notes: "Oliver Goldsmith (10 November 1728 – 4 April 1774) was a well known Anglo-Irish novelist, playwright, dramatist and poet,"

Author: Orhan Pamuk
Annotator Notes: "Pamuk was born in Istanbul, in 1952, and he grew up in a wealthy yet declining upper-class family"

Author: Orson Scott Card
Annotator Notes: "Card's family has Mormon pioneer heritage."

Author: Oscar Wilde
Annotator Notes: "Wilde's parents were Anglo-Irish intellectuals in Dublin."

Author: Patricia McCormick
Annotator Notes: "Patricia McCormick (born May 23, 1956) is an American journalist and writer "

Author: Patrick Flores-Scott
Annotator Notes: "I was born and raised in the Snoqualmie Valley (just east of Seattle), in the dark, wet foothills of Washington's Cascade Mountains.  My dad is a life-long Valley-ite, and my mom is from Uruguay.  This meant my two sisters and I were comfortable being scolded in either Spanish or English"

Author: Patrisse Cullors
Annotator Notes: "Patrisse has been honored with various awards including: The Sydney Peace Prize Award (2017), Black Woman of the Year Award (2015) from The National Congress of Black Women, Civil Rights Leader for the 21st Century Award (2015) from the Los Angeles Times, Community Change Agent Award (2016) from BLACK GIRLS ROCK!, Inc., Women of the Year Award for the Justice Seekers Award (2016) from Glamour, and ESSENCE’ first-ever Woke Award.

Author: asha bandele
Annotator Notes: "asha bandele first attained recognition when she penned her 1999 debut book, The Prisoner’s Wife, a powerful, lyrical memoir about a young Black woman’s romance and marriage with a man who was serving a twenty-to-life sentence in prison"

Author: Paula Hawkins
Annotator Notes: Paula Hawkin's Wikipedia page is categorized under "White Zimbabwean people"

Author: Paule Marshall
Annotator Notes: "Paule Marshall, Influential Black Novelist, Dies at 90

Author: Paulo Coelho
Annotator Notes: "Coelho was raised in Rio de Janeiro. He rebelled against the conventions of his Roman Catholic upbringing

Author: Philip Roth
Annotator Notes: "Roth's family was Jewish, and his parents were second-generation Americans"

Author: Piri Thomas
Annotator Notes: "Thomas was also exposed to racial discrimination because of his Afro-Latino heritage."

Author: Pulma Gobodo-Madikizela
Annotator Notes: "Like most Black South Africans of her generation who were active in student politics, both her high-school and university years were interrupted by expulsions

Author: Ralph Ellison
Annotator Notes: "Ellison applied twice for admission to Tuskegee Institute, the prestigious all-black university in Alabama founded by Booker T. Washington."

Author: Randy Ribay
Annotator Notes: "Randy Ribay was born in the Philippines and raised in the Midwest

Author: Raquel Cepeda
Annotator Notes: "Raquel Cepeda is an American journalist, critic, film-maker, and autobiographer of Dominican descent."

Author: Ray Bradbury
Annotator Notes: "Bradbury was born in Waukegan, Illinois, to Esther (née Moberg) Bradbury (1888–1966), a Swedish immigrant, and Leonard Spaulding Bradbury (1890–1957), a power and telephone lineman of English ancestry"

Author: Rebecca Skloot
Annotator Notes: " Skloot said, "in the Pacific Northwest, [her] roots [are] half New York Jew and half Midwestern Protestant.

Author: Reyna Grande
Annotator Notes: "Reyna Grande (born 7 September 1975, Iguala, Guerrero, Mexico) is a Mexican author living in the United States.

Author: Richard Hughes
Annotator Notes: "He was born in Weybridge, Surrey. His father was Arthur Hughes, a civil servant, and his mother Louisa Grace Warren who had been brought up in the West Indies in Jamaica.

Author: Richard Wright
Annotator Notes: "His parents were born free after the Civil War; both sets of his grandparents had been born into slavery and freed as a result of the war. Each of his grandfathers had taken part in the U.S. Civil War and gained freedom through service"

Author: Rigoberta Menchu
Annotator Notes: "Rigoberta Menchú was born to a poor Indigenous family of K'iche' Maya descent in Laj Chimel, a rural area in the north-central Guatemalan province of El Quiché.[5] Her family was one of many Indigenous families who could not sustain themselves"

Author: Robert Caro
Annotator Notes: "Caro was born in New York City, the son of Jewish parents

Author: Robert Penn Warren
Annotator Notes: "Warren's mother's family had roots in Virginia, having given their name to the community of Penn's Store in Patrick County, Virginia, and she was a descendant of Revolutionary War soldier Colonel Abram Penn"

Author: Robertson Davies
Annotator Notes: "(William) Rupert Davies (12 September 1879 – 11 March 1967) was a Welsh-Canadian author, editor, newspaper publisher, and politician" "Davies was the father of author Robertson Davies, Arthur Davies and Fred Davies. "

Author: Rohinton Mistry
Annotator Notes: "Rohinton Mistry CM (born 1952) is an Indian-born Canadian writer.

Author: Rudolfo Anaya
Annotator Notes: "His father, Martín Anaya, was a vaquero from a family of cattle workers and sheepherders. His mother, Rafaelita (Mares), was from a family composed of farmers from Puerto De Luna in the Pecos Valley of New Mexico

Author: Ruth Ozeki
Annotator Notes: "The daughter of a Japanese mother and a Caucasian-American father, she was born and raised in New Haven, Connecticut."

Author: S. E. Hinton
Annotator Notes: "Susan Eloise Hinton (born July 22, 1948) is an American writer best known for her young-adult novels (YA) set in Oklahoma"

Author: Salman Rushdie
Annotator Notes: "Ahmed Salman Rushdie[9] was born in Bombay on 19 June 1947[10] during the British Raj, into an Indian Kashmiri Muslim family.

Author: Sandra Cisneros
Annotator Notes: "regarded as a key figure in Chicano literature"

Author: Sapphire
Annotator Notes: "Lofton took the name "Sapphire" because of its one-time cultural association with the image of a "belligerent black woman,"

Author: Sarah Orne Jewett
Annotator Notes: "Sarah Orne Jewett was born in South Berwick, Maine on September 3, 1849. Her family had been residents of New England for many generations."

Author: Saul Bellow
Annotator Notes: "Saul Bellow was born Solomon Bellows[9][10] in Lachine, Quebec, two years after his parents, Lescha (née Gordin) and Abraham Bellows,[11] emigrated from Saint Petersburg, Russia"

Author: Selamawi Asgedom
Annotator Notes: Selamawi Asgedom or Mawi Asgedom for short, is an author, public speaker, and a refugee of Ethiopian and Eritrean origin

Author: Sharon G. Flake
Annotator Notes: "She has also won two Coretta Scott King Awards.[2]"

Author: Sherman Alexie
Annotator Notes: "Sherman Joseph Alexie Jr. is a Spokane-Coeur d'Alene-Native American novelist"

Author: Shirley Jackson
Annotator Notes: "Jackson also churned out stories and novels that probed the psyches of abuse survivors, tackled the symptoms of dissociative disorder, and lambasted the casual anti-Semitism and racism that was common among her fellow 1950s Americans.

Author: Shobha Rao
Annotator Notes: "Shobha Rao, an immigrant from India, recalls two interactions with her peers that reminded her of when she helped her parents say “yes” to remaining in America."

Author: Sinclair Lewis
Annotator Notes: "I was born in a prairie village in that most Scandinavian part of America, Minnesota, the son of a country doctor, in 1885"

Author: Sister Souljah
Annotator Notes: " She felt that she was being taught very little of her history, since the junior high school and high school left out Black history, art, and culture."

Author: Solomon Northup
Annotator Notes: "A free-born African American from New York, he was the son of a freed slave and a free woman of color. "

Author: Sonia Nazario
Annotator Notes: "She has been named among the most influential Latinos by Hispanic Business Magazine and a “trendsetter” by Hispanic Magazine.

Author: Stephanie Kallos
Annotator Notes: "Stephanie Kallos was born in Idaho and grew up in Nebraska"

Author: Stephen Chbosky
Annotator Notes: "He is the son of Lea (née Meyer), a tax preparer, and Fred G. Chbosky, a steel company executive and consultant to CFOs." "He was raised Catholic"

Author: Stephen Crane
Annotator Notes: "The Cranes were descended from Jaspar Crane, a founder of New Haven Colony, who had migrated there from England in 1639

Author: Stephen King
Annotator Notes: "Even if he weren’t a 72-year-old unspeakably rich White man who has spent the bulk of his life in a state whose Black population has never broken 5% — Maine is literally the Whitest state in the country — those things would be true for all White people.

Author: Sue Monk Kidd
Annotator Notes: "Sue Monk Kidd (born August 12, 1948) is an American writer from Sylvester, Georgia "

Author: Sun-Mi Hwang
Annotator Notes: "Hwang Seon-mi (born 1963) is a South Korean author and professor

Author: Suzanne Collins
Annotator Notes: "Born in Hartford, Connecticut on August 10, 1962, Collins is the daughter of a U.S. Air Force officer"

Author: Sylvia Plath
Annotator Notes: "Her mother, Aurelia Schober Plath (1906–1994), was a second-generation American of Austrian descent, and her father, Otto Plath (1885–1940), was from Grabow, Mecklenburg-Schwerin, Germany"

Author: Ta-Nehisi Coates
Annotator Notes: "Ta-Nehisi Coates is one of the most original and perceptive black voices today

Author: Tara Westover
Annotator Notes: "Westover was the youngest of seven children born in Clifton, Idaho (population 259) to Mormon survivalist parents. "

Author: Theodore Dreiser
Annotator Notes: "Dreiser was born in Terre Haute, Indiana, to John Paul Dreiser and Sarah Maria (née Schanab).[3] John Dreiser was a German immigrant from Mayen in the Rhine Province of Prussia, and Sarah was from the Mennonite farming community near Dayton, Ohio. "

Author: Thomas Hardy
Annotator Notes: "Thomas Hardy was born on 2 June, 1840 in Higher Bockhampton (then Upper Bockhampton), a hamlet in the parish of Stinsford to the east of Dorchester in Dorset, England, where his father Thomas (1811–1892) worked as a stonemason and local builder"

Author: Thomas Mann
Annotator Notes: "Paul Thomas Mann was born to a bourgeois family in Lübeck, the second son of Thomas Johann Heinrich Mann (a senator and a grain merchant) and his wife Júlia da Silva Bruhns, a Brazilian woman of German and Portuguese ancestry, who emigrated to Germany with her family when she was seven years old"

Author: Thomas More
Annotator Notes: :Born on Milk Street in the City of London, on 7 February 1478, Thomas More was the son of Sir John More,[15] a successful lawyer and later a judge,[9] and his wife Agnes (née Graunger). He was the second of six children. More was educated at St. Anthony's School, then considered one of London's best schools."

Author: Thomas Wolfe
Annotator Notes: "Wolfe was born in Asheville, North Carolina", "His father, a successful stone carver, ran a gravestone business."

Author: Tim O'Brien
Annotator Notes: "Tim O'Brien (born October 1, 1946) is an American novelist who served as a soldier in the Vietnam War."

Author: Tobias Wolff
Annotator Notes: "Wolff was born in 1945 in Birmingham, Alabama, the second son of Rosemary (Loftus) from Hartford, Connecticut, and Arthur Samuels Wolff, an aeronautical engineer who was a son of a Jewish doctor and his wife"

Author: Tommy Orange
Annotator Notes: " According to a New York Times review, Orange's father was a Native American ceremony leader, while his mother converted for a time to Christianity."

Author: Toni Morrison
Annotator Notes: "Toni Morrison was born Chloe Ardelia Wofford,[2] the second of four children from a working-class, Black family, in Lorain, Ohio, to Ramah (née Willis) and George Wofford."

Author: Trevor Noah
Annotator Notes: "His father, Robert, is of Swiss-German ancestry, and his mother, Patricia Nombuyiselo Noah, is Xhosa

Author: Truman Capote
Annotator Notes: "Truman Garcia Capote[1] (/kəˈpoʊti/ kə-POH-tee;[2] born Truman Streckfus Persons; September 30, 1924 – August 25, 1984) was an American novelist, screenwriter, playwright and actor."

Author: Tsitsi Dangarembga
Annotator Notes: "Her debut novel, Nervous Conditions (1988), which was the first to be published in English by a Black woman from Zimbabwe"

Author: Upton Sinclair
Annotator Notes: "Both of Upton Sinclair's parents were of British ancestry. "

Author: V. S. Naipaul
Annotator Notes: "Trinidadian writer of Indian descent"

Author: Veronica Roth
Annotator Notes: "Roth is of German and Polish descent."

Author: Virginia Woolf
Annotator Notes: "Woolf was born into an affluent household in South Kensington, London, the seventh child of Julia Prinsep Jackson and Leslie Stephen"

Author: Vladimir Nabokov
Annotator Notes: "His family traced its roots to the 14th-century Tatar prince Nabok Murza, who entered into the service of the Tsars,"

Author: Voltaire
Annotator Notes: "François-Marie Arouet was born in Paris, the youngest of the five children of François Arouet (1649–1722), a lawyer who was a minor treasury official, and his wife, Marie Marguerite Daumard (c. 1660–1701), whose family was on the lowest rank of the French nobility."

Author: W. O. Mitchell
Annotator Notes: "William Ormond Mitchell, PC OC (March 13, 1914 – February 25, 1998) was a Canadian writer and broadcaster."

Author: Wallace Stegner
Annotator Notes: "Wallace Earle Stegner (February 18, 1909 – April 13, 1993) was an American novelist, short story writer, environmentalist, and historian,"

Author: Waubgeshig Rice
Annotator Notes: "Waubgeshig Rice is an author and journalist from Wasauksing First Nation on Georgian Bay."

Author: Wes Moore
Annotator Notes: "he is the first Black governor of the state"

Author: Willa Cather
Annotator Notes: "The Cather family originated in Wales"

Author: William Faulkner
Annotator Notes: "illiam Faulkner (1897-1962), who came from an old southern family, grew up in Oxford, Mississippi. "

Author: William Golding
Annotator Notes: "Sir William Gerald Golding CBE FRSL (19 September 1911 – 19 June 1993) was a British novelist, playwright, and poet."

Author: William Styron
Annotator Notes: "William Clark Styron Jr. (June 11, 1925 – November 1, 2006) was an American novelist and essayist who won major literary awards for his work."

Author: William Wells Brown
Annotator Notes: "William was of mixed race; his father was George W. Higgins, a white planter and cousin of his master Dr. Young." "his mother Elizabeth was a slave"

Author: Yaa Gyasi
Annotator Notes: "Yaa Gyasi (born 1989) is a Ghanaian-American novelist. "

Author: Yann Martel
Annotator Notes: "Martel was born in Salamanca, Spain, in 1963 to French-Canadians Émile Martel and Nicole Perron "

Author: Zadie Smith
Annotator Notes: "Sadie Smith was born on 25 October 1975[3] in Willesden[4] to a Jamaican mother, Yvonne Bailey, and an English father, Harvey Smith,[5] who was 30 years his wife's senior"

Author: Zora Neale Hurston
Annotator Notes: "Hurston became the most successful and most significant black woman writer of the first half of the 20th century"
